journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: A numerical study of the effects of blade angle distribution on the performance and loss generation of centrifugal compressor impellers

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Pohang University of Science and Technology, Pohang, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: *Department of Mechanical Engineering, Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH), San31, Hyoja-dong, Nam-gu, Pohang 790-784, Republic of Korea. email: jhbaek@postech.ac.kr

abstract.p: The blade angle distribution from the inlet to outlet of an impeller in a centrifugal compressor is known to have significant influence on its flow characteristics. With the aim of understanding the effect of the blade angle distribution, particularly on performance, loss generation, and operating range, four different blade angle distributions were defined with fixed inlet and outlet blade angles, and numerical calculations were conducted over their whole operating ranges, as defined by their stall points and choke conditions. The impeller blade Blade80, which has the smallest variation of blade angle and is relatively radial, was found to exhibit the smallest wall skin friction loss due to its small surface area but the highest blade loading loss. Further, the flow separation near the hub at the suction side and the tip and resulting energy loss give rise to the smallest stall margin of the blades. In contrast, Blade110, which has the largest variation of blade angle, exhibits the largest wall skin friction and hub-to-shroud loading losses but the lowest blade loading loss because the flow from the inlet to the outlet is well guided. As the flow coefficient increases, the performance of Blade110 steeply decreases. The poor performance of Blade110 at high mass flowrates can be explained in terms of flow blockage at the narrow throat. An attempt is made to explain the relationships between the blade angle distributions and the flow characteristics, loss generation, and performance of these impellers.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Centrifugal compressors are generally used in aeronautical and industrial applications with relatively high pressure ratios and small mass flowrates. The current aim of the design of centrifugal compressors is to improve their overall performance and at the same time preserve their operating ranges and reduce machine size. Although this aim has resulted in abundant experimental and numerical studies of the detailed flow physics inside centrifugal compressors, many aspects of their flow physics still remain to be fully elucidated.

The geometry of the impeller has significant effects on the overall performance of the centrifugal compressor because the flow development inside the impeller not only determines the aerodynamic efficiency of the impeller itself, but also strongly affects the efficiency of the downstream diffuser or volute [1–9]. The flow inside impellers is highly three-dimensional (3D) and complex in its dependence on the interactions between various geometrical parameters and the flow conditions, and is thus responsible for energy loss, flow non-uniformity, and system instability. To investigate the relationships between the geometrical parameters and performance, many researchers have studied the flow characteristics inside centrifugal compressors with various impeller shapes using computational fluid dynamics and experiments.

The design and optimization of impellers have been extensively studied. Bonaiuti et al. [1] used a design of experiments technique to analyse and optimize transonic centrifugal compressor impellers and to determine the correlations between input geometrical parameters and impeller performance. They found that varying the hub meridional blade angle distribution had greater effects on efficiency than varying the shroud meridional blade angle distribution. Hildebrandt and Genrup [2] compared the flow fields and performances of impellers with two different back sweep angles and three different exducer widths. Roytta et al. [3] performed a numerical study of three different shrouded two-dimensional impellers to determine the effects on performance of varying the meridional blade angle distribution; they found that efficiency significantly varies with the blade angle distribution and that the hypothesis that pressure losses in a curved duct and in an impeller passage behave similarly is inadequate. Kim et al. [4] optimized the meridional contours and blade angles of a centrifugal compressor impeller and the number of diffuser vanes using the response surface method and the design of experiments technique and achieved higher efficiency and better performance through this optimization process.

The blade angles at the leading and trailing edges of impellers are primarily determined in the initial one-dimensional (1D) design phase by considering the design mass flowrate, the rotational speed, and the system dimensions. The local blade angle distribution from the impeller inlet to the outlet changes the curvature of the channel and the acceleration/deceleration of the flow and is known to significantly affect the blade loading from inlet to outlet, the flow separation, and finally the jet-wake pattern at the impeller outlet. In contrast to the blade angles at the leading and trailing edges, which can be determined rather simply, the impeller blade angle distribution is often empirically designed and modified using an inverse design method. In this approach, the impeller meridional blade angle distribution is determined by calculating the blade loading along the blade with the assumption of compressible inviscid flow [5] and then modifying the initial shape to create a favourable blade loading. However, the general weaknesses of this method in centrifugal compressors are the complicated geometries it results in, and the inaccuracy of the flow prediction method used. In order to achieve a highly advanced and sophisticated design, a compressible viscous flow analysis with many iterative steps of modification that simultaneously considers the extension of the operating range and performance is required, but this approach is very time-consuming.

Although the blade angle distribution from the inlet to outlet of an impeller in a centrifugal compressor is known to have significant influence on both its efficiency and the operating ranges, there have been few literatures dealing with the blade angle distributions of 3D impellers and their effect on flow development. In this article, the influence of the blade angle distributions of 3D impellers on their flow characteristics, secondary flows, and performance are examined. The calculations were conducted over the whole operating ranges defined by the stall points and choke conditions of the blades. The optimal design configuration has not been determined, but the results do provide useful insights into the relationship between blade angle distribution and performance, and thus can help designers to reduce the number of iterative modification steps after the primary design process and to design more effective centrifugal compressor impellers. By modifying the impeller used in a previous study [6], several new blade angle distributions have been defined. The numerical results of this study have been used for these impellers to estimate the individual loss components with correlations, and compare their flow characteristics and loss generation according to the occurrence of secondary flows at various mass flowrates.

sec.title: 2 COMPRESSOR DESCRIPTION AND NUMERICAL PROCEDURES
sec.p:
The compressor stage under consideration has a 15-blade backswept impeller and a vaneless diffuser. The impeller is unshrouded with a constant tip clearance of 0.3 mm from the leading edge to the trailing edge. The blade angles at the inlet tip, inlet hub, outlet tip, and outlet hub are −62°, −43°, −42°, and −40° from the meridional plane, respectively. The vaneless diffuser consists of parallel walls with a constant height of 5 mm. The meridional parameters and main specifications of the impeller are shown in Fig. 1 and Table 1. The radius of the location where flow variables are calculated is 75.0 mm, which is slightly larger than that of the impeller trailing edge. The design specifications for the flow calculations are listed in Table 2, and a 3D view of the impeller is shown in Fig. 2. Fig. 1
Geometrical configuration and parameters of the compressor impeller Fig. 2
Full 3D view of the compressor impeller Table 1
Specification of the geometrical parameters
Blade number 15
Inlet hub diameter, D1H 36.0 mm
Inlet shroud diameter, D1S 71.5 mm
Inlet hub angle −43° (from meridional)
Inlet tip angle −62° (from meridional)
Outlet diameter, D2 140.0 mm
Outlet hub angle −40° (from meridional)
Outlet tip angle −42° (from meridional)
Axial length, Δx 34.4 mm
Blade width, B2 5.0 mm
Tip clearance 0.3 mm
Table 2
Aerodynamic specifications
Inlet total pressure 100000 Pa
Inlet total temperature 298 K
Outlet mass flowrate 0.3 kg/s (per machine)
Rotational speed 50 000 r/min
Specific heat ratio 1.4
Design flow coefficient, ϕd 0.228
Total pressure ratio 2.48
Reynolds number 8.41 × 105
Mach number 0.533

A 3D Reynolds-averaged Navier–Stokes solver by finite volume method with hybrid unstructured grid, ANSYS CFX 12.0 [10], was used to obtain the flow field of the impeller. The k–ω shear stress transport (SST) model was employed for turbulence modelling and a hexahedral computational mesh generated. The total pressure and total temperature were imposed at inlet as boundary conditions, and the mass flowrate was fixed at the impeller outlet.

In order to investigate the grid dependency of the impeller geometry, three kinds of grid systems were generated: 96 958 nodes for Grid 1 529 796 nodes for Grid 2 and 1 051 596 nodes for Grid 3, and blade loading distribution at mid-span for each grid at ϕ/ϕd of 1.0 is compared in Fig. 3. It is confirmed that there is no significant difference between Grids 2 and 3, and Grid 2 can be considered a fine mesh enough for flow analysis without any grid dependency of the results. Fig. 3
The comparison of blade loading distribution at mid-span at ϕ/ϕd = 1.0

Based on the grid dependency test, one passage of the impeller was discretized by 529 796 nodes totally and 12 nodes for tip clearance gap were used for the calculation. In the vicinity of the blade, O-grid was imposed to reduce grid skewness and obtain the high-quality mesh. Steady computations were performed on a single blade passage using periodic boundary condition. For each computation, convergence was assumed when a steady value of the root mean square of the residuals was reached. Details of 3D grids at the impeller and hub surfaces are illustrated in Fig. 4. To validate the numerical investigations with CFX, numerical results were compared with experimental ones in the author’s previous study [6], showing good quantitative and qualitative agreements over most operating ranges. Figure 5 shows the centrifugal compressor impeller used in the experiment. Fig. 4
Blade-to-blade surface grid of the impeller Fig. 5
Photograph of the centrifugal compressor impeller

In this computation, the stall was numerically defined as the lowest mass flowrate for which the calculation reaches convergence, and the choke was defined as a point just before the time when the outlet pressure value continuously decreases with no convergence, and the mass flowrate calculated at the inlet does not match the mass flowrate imposed at the outlet as a boundary condition.

sec.title: 3 MERIDIONAL BLADE ANGLE DISTRIBUTIONS
sec.p:
The blade angle β from the meridional plane is defined by correlating with the azimuthal coordinate of the camber line θ through the relation (1) where s is the curvilinear abscissa along the blade and r the local radius. In order to investigate the effects of varying the blade angle on flow characteristics and performance, the blade angle distribution from the leading edge to the trailing are, discretized by spline curve points, was varied by multiplying the values of the initial points with four different factors (0.8, 0.9, 1.0, and 1.1) while fixing the inlet and outlet angles, as shown in Figs 6(a) and (b). In Fig. 6, the blade angle distributions from the leading edge to the trailing edge at the hub and shroud are compared for the four blades with multiplying factors 0.8, 0.9, 1.0, and 1.1, which were named Blade80, Blade90, Blade100, and Blade110, respectively. The four different blade shapes are compared at mid-span in Fig. 7. Since the blade angle is measured from the meridional plane, as the absolute value of β becomes large, the blade has high turning and correspondingly, the blade surface area and the passage length also increase. The blade surface areas of Blade80, Blade90, and Blade110 are 96.1 per cent, 98.0 per cent, and 102.5 per cent of that of the original blade. Fig. 6
β Distributions from the leading edge to the trailing edge at (a) hub and (b) shroud Fig. 7
The mid-span geometries of the four different blades from inlet to outlet

sec.title: 4 RESULTS AND PERFORMANCE CURVES
sec.p:
Steady calculations were conducted for the four cases, Blade80, Blade90, Blade100, and Blade110, at various mass flowrates and the results are plotted in Fig. 8 with respect to the normalized mass flowrate (ϕ/ϕd). As seen in Fig. 8(a), Blade80, Blade90, and Blade100 have almost the same total pressure ratio and the original blade has the highest efficiency at the design flowrate. The total pressure ratio for Blade110 is the lowest over the whole operating range. As the flow rate increases, the total pressure ratio and the total-to-total efficiency for Blade80 become significantly higher than those of the other blades. On the other hand, the performance of Blade110 steeply decreases as the mass flowrate increases. Fig. 8
Performance characteristics of the blades: (a) total pressure ratio and (b) total-to-total efficiency

sec.title: 5 FLOW ANALYSIS – LOSSES IN THE IMPELLERS
sec.p: The flow within the centrifugal compressor is highly complex because of 3D effects and unsteadiness, and hence many researchers have tried to investigate the loss mechanisms in order to understand the complex flow physics of the centrifugal compressor. Unfortunately, the loss mechanisms are still not clearly understood and so individual loss components can seldom be accurately predicted.

According to the results of studies of loss mechanisms in turbomachinery [11, 12], entropy generation results from losses such as incidence, skin friction, blade loading, hub-to-shroud loading, distortion, blade clearance, and mixing losses. Aungier [12] developed a loss model for a centrifugal compressor with a 1D approach that could be applied to our flow analysis. Although 1D approaches are usually highly idealized and oversimplified, they can reveal the qualitative properties of loss generation in centrifugal compressor impellers. The exact quantitative estimations of the loss components are too complex and difficult and beyond the scope of this article.

Skin friction loss is the loss resulting from wall friction due to the boundary layers between the flow and the blade surface. The total pressure loss coefficient due to skin friction can be calculated as follows [12] (2)

Since skin friction loss is proportional to the length of the blade mean camber line, Blade110, with the largest variation of blade angle and the longest mean camber line, is expected to exhibit higher skin friction loss than the shorter blades. In Fig. 9, the wall skin friction losses of the blades calculated from the correlation are normalized by the value for Blade100: the largest wall skin friction loss occurs in Blade110, as expected. Fig. 9
Comparison of the magnitudes of the loss components normalized by the value for Blade100 at ϕ/ϕd = 1.0

Blade loading loss results from blade-to-blade pressure gradients that produce secondary flows and lead to blade stall and can be calculated using equation (3) [12] (3) When a blade has a small variation of blade angle and is relatively radial (e.g. Blade80), the passage from inlet to outlet is short and the flow cross-sectional area changes more rapidly because the inlet and outlet areas are the same for the four blades. Since the flow will not be perfectly guided because the passage length is too short and the cross-sectional area rapidly changes, blade-to-blade energy loss is produced and a lower energy region arises from the suction side to the mid-passage region. In Fig. 9, it can be seen that the blade loading loss increases as the variation of blade angle becomes smaller.

Hub-to-shroud loading loss is analogous to blade loading loss but arises in the hub-to-shroud direction and can be calculated as shown [12] (4) As seen in Fig. 9, the hub-to-shroud loading losses of Blade80, Blade90, and Blade100 are the same and that of Blade110 is higher. This difference can be explained in terms of the entropy contours directly related to loss generation.

Figure 10 shows the entropy contours at plane 100 for Blade80, Blade100, and Blade110. Entropy accumulates at the outlet from every source of loss inside the impeller. In Fig. 10, the region of high entropy is larger on the suction side than on the pressure side, which indicates the accumulation of low energy fluid due to the secondary flow that results from the blade loading, which induces the formation of a pressure gradient from the suction surface to the pressure surface. Lower entropy generation is observed on the hub surface and arises because the centrifugal force causes low energy fluid to accumulate in the vicinity of the casing due to the axial to radial bend of the centrifugal compressor impeller. This distinct concentration of high loss in the vicinity of the suction side and casing is a well-known jet-wake flow pattern at the exits of impellers. Fig. 10
Entropy contours at plane 100 for Blade80 (top), Blade100 (middle), and Blade110 (bottom) at ϕ/ϕd = 1.0

For Blade80, a high-entropy region spreads out over the suction side, tip, and mid-passage regions, which explains the higher blade loading loss evident in Fig. 9. In contrast, in the case of Blade110, the high-entropy region near the suction side extends to the hub surface, which explains the higher hub-to-shroud loading loss in Fig. 9.

Strictly speaking, the blade rake angles also change with the changes in the blade angles from the hub to shroud, as shown in Fig. 10; so the flow characteristics in the impellers might also be affected by the rake angle changes. To separate the combined effects of blade angle and rake angle changes on the flows inside the impellers, further calculation and analysis are required.

The streamwise velocities averaged in the circumferential direction at plane 100 from hub to shroud for Blade80, Blade100, and Blade110 are shown in Fig. 11. There is a higher velocity region for Blade80 near the hub with a reverse flow region near the tip. The reverse flow region near the tip of Blade80 corresponds to the high-entropy region near the tip, as shown in Fig. 10. Fig. 11
Averaged streamwise velocities from hub to shroud at plane 100 at ϕ/ϕd = 1.0

sec.title: 6 OFF-DESIGN ANALYSIS
sec.p:
To analyse the lower and higher limits of the operating ranges for the blades, the choke and stall margins are defined as follows (5) (6) (7) As observed from the data given in Table 3, when the multiplying factor increases, the SM increases. In contrast to the favourable effects on SM of increasing the variation of blade angle, the CM tends to decrease with increases in the variation of blade angle. Further, compared to the other shapes, Blade90 has the widest operating range and the Blade110 a narrow one. Thus, there is a clear relationship between blade angle distribution and CM or SM, and the variation in OR is determined by the values of CM and SM. Table 3
Dimensionless parameters CM, SM, and OR for the blades
Blade80 Blade90 Blade100 Blade110
CM 0.79 0.70 0.62 0.50
SM 0.01 0.11 0.16 0.17
OR 0.80 0.81 0.78 0.67

sec.title: 6.1 At a low flowrate (ϕ/ϕd = 0.9)
sec.p:
In Fig. 8 and Table 3, it can be seen that when the variation of blade angle is small, stall occurs earlier (nearer to the design mass flowrate). Stall occurs when the velocity energy is too small to penetrate the passage with a highly adverse pressure gradient. It is known that radial blades are vulnerable to stall because adverse pressure gradient is large for the same pressure rise due to short blade passage length. The stall limit of Blade80 is at a ϕ/ϕd value of 0.99; in Fig. 12, the tangential flow vector of Blade90 at plane 25 is compared to that of Blade110. Since plane 25 is not perpendicular to the main flow direction, the circumferential velocity component of the main flow is also partially represented in Fig. 12. For Blade90, the hub corner separation becomes large near the suction side and the vortex near the casing is also large. These secondary flows result in an unstable flow stream, which is likely to have triggered the earlier stall. Fig. 12
Secondary flow vectors at plane 25 for Blade90 (left) and Blade110 (right) at ϕ/ϕd = 0.9

sec.title: 6.2 At a high flowrate (ϕ/ϕd = 1.5)
sec.p:
It is obvious that throat area is a critical parameter that determines the choke limit. For Blade80, Blade90, and Blade110, the throat areas are 110.9 per cent, 105.5 per cent, and 92.7 per cent of the throat area of Blade100. Since Blade110 has the narrowest throat, flow is likely to abnormally pass through the throat and so the total pressure is likely to drop near the throat, as shown in Fig. 13. Abnormal flow can also be seen in Fig. 14, as evident in the limiting streamlines at the blade suction surfaces of Blade100 and Blade110. In contrast to the original blade, for which there is a smooth streamline from the blade leading edge to the trailing one, Blade110 has an unfavourable conveying streamline at the position of the throat, which is not seen in other cases or for other mass flowrates. Fig. 13
Total pressure from inlet to outlet at ϕ/ϕd = 1.5 Fig. 14
Limiting streamlines at the blade suction surfaces for Blade100 (left) and Blade110 (right) at ϕ/ϕd = 1.5

Further, Fig. 15 shows the blade loading distributions at mid-span for Blade80, Blade90, Blade100, and Blade110 at a ϕ/ϕd value of 1.5. From the leading edge to 20 per cent of the normalized meridional length, an adverse blade loading and an unfavourable pressure distribution on both the suction and pressure sides are found for Blade110. From Figs 13 to 15, it is concluded that too high blade turning can lead to serious blockage phenomena at the throat, abnormal flow patterns, and an earlier choke. Fig. 15
Mid-span blade loading distributions at ϕ/ϕd = 1.5

sec.title: 7 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p:
In this article, four blades with different blade angle distributions were designed and the flow physics inside each impeller was analysed. The angle distributions were varied by multiplying the blade angle of the original blade by various factors (0.8, 0.9, and 1.1) with fixed inlet and outlet angles. The 3D Navier–Stokes solver ANSYS CFX 12.0 was used to investigate the flow phenomena with the aim of determining guidelines for better performance. The following results were obtained.
The comparison of the wall skin friction, blade loading, and hub-to-shroud loading losses of Blade80, Blade90, Blade100, and Blade110 at the design mass flowrate shows that wall skin friction loss increases as the variation of blade angle increases because the increase in the blade surface area. Blade110 leads to the lowest blade loading loss since the flow from the inlet to the outlet is well-guided; but, it also leads to the highest hub-to-shroud loading loss and a higher entropy region near the hub surface.
By comparing the operating ranges defined by the SM and CM, it was shown that the SM of Blade110 is higher but that it also has a drastically decreased CM. In contrast, for Blade80, the SM is almost unchanged but it has a significantly increased CM. Because of the compromise between a larger SM for a larger variation of blade angle and a larger CM for a smaller variation of blade angle, Blade90 has the widest operating range and Blade110 the narrowest operating range.
At a low mass flowrate (ϕ/ϕd = 0.9), a flow separation region near the hub at the suction side and a vortex region near the tip form more strongly for Blade90. The accumulation of energy loss due to unstable secondary flows is the main reason for the difficulty in going through the passage with a highly adverse pressure gradient in a relatively radial blade.
When the flow coefficients are high, Blade110 exhibits steeply reduced performance and has a much smaller CM than the other blades. At a high mass flowrate (ϕ/ϕd = 1.5), an unfavourable streamline on the suction side and a low total pressure from inlet to outlet result from the blockage to the flow at the throat.

As a final consideration, it is possible that the blade angle distribution can be optimized. Blade80 has a small variation of blade angle, is relatively radial, and tends to exhibit high blade loading loss and tip leakage loss, whereas a high wall skin friction loss and a hub-to-shroud loading loss arise for Blade110, which has a larger blade turning. Further, SM and CM and operating ranges are considerably affected by varying the blade angles with fixed inlet and outlet angles. Finding the optimum blade angle distribution once the inlet and outlet angles have been determined in the primary design step seems to be a promising approach to the design of compressor impellers with high performance. Furthermore, a related study of the effects of varying the blade angle distribution on the unsteady flow interaction between the impeller and the vaned diffuser, as described in previous papers [4, 6], is underway.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This study was supported by the Korea Institute of Machinery and Materials (KIMM) and BK21.
